text:
Should Manchester have a music museum? How to get tickets for the Manchester Music Legacies Centre debate Industry experts want your ideas on how to celebrate Manchester's music scene Share Ian Brown of The Stone Roses (Photo: Ryan Phillips/PA Wire) Share Get What's On updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
It's clear that Manchester has a music scene worth shouting about. 
The Stone Roses and The Smiths - to name just two - influenced a generation, and more recently Whyte Horses , Cabbage , and Blossoms are turning into major players on the music circuit. 
But what's the best way to celebrate the city's talent? 
A museum dedicated to Manchester music is one idea, and on Wednesday March 1 some of the finest minds in the Manchester are having a public discourse to flesh out possible plans - and you can be there to have your say. 
Join the chair Dave Haslam, former Smiths member Mike Joyce, music festival mogul Jon Drape, Manchester District Music Archive rep Abigail Ward, lecturer and musician Susan O'Shea, and our very own What's On editor Simon Binns in a discussion about how best to preserve musical heritage and inspire future generations. 
The event, which takes place in The Old Cornerhouse on Oxford Street, is organised by civic movement Manchester Shield - a non-party political movement seeking to unite the voices of Manchester to help shape the development of the city. Stockport band Blossoms (Photo: Danny North) Read More Clint Boon leaves Radio X and BBC to take over XS Manchester radio drive time slot 
In preparation for the debate, the group have run a survey in which they found that 98% of 295 responses felt to not having a music museum was a missed opportunity for Manchester. 
According to the Manchester Shield, 60% of respondents felt that the project could be damaged if the wrong partners were found, and 71% of people were concerned if the project had the wrong creative leaders who were not well established or passionate Mancunians, a music legacies centre might be doomed to failure. 
Dave Haslam who is chairing the debate says “initially I was sceptical because a lot of people are concerned that such a music centre could be regressive and would totally focus on the past, even if just for the music tourism economy." 
"However, it seems there might be good ideas for a centre that go far beyond being a nostalgic museum and they could inspire the legacies of the next Manchester musicians and could have a huge educational value . How such a centre might work best in practice, or even if it necessary seems worth debating”. Cabbage performing at Gorilla (Photo: Vincent Cole) 
Abigail Wards from Manchester District Music Archive adds: "before becoming an online archive we campaigned for a museum dedicated to Greater Manchester's fascinating and varied musical histories. We continue to be passionate about revealing hidden histories and highlighting the unsung contributors to our region's music story. 
"We feel a music centre should reflect this and explore the social and political histories that intertwine with music. We also believe that a centre of this kind is only relevant if it looks forward. It must support and inspire fledgling musicians, artists and other emerging talents. It must present and attract a diverse range of voices". 
Tickets for the debate cost £3.78 including booking fee and are available via Eventbrite . 
The Manchester Music Legacies debate is donating all ticket proceeds to The Horsfall , whose work to improve mental health and well-being for young people through engagement the creative arts. Read More
